content.raw:
Thanks for your contribution @{557058:054df869-5cda-48f2-8b4e-81a61c133346}. 

Is there a specific reason for not using the `JointVelocityCmd` for resetting joint velocities? I understand we don't have a component for setting joint positions so I see the need for `JointPositionReset`, but would it be a problem if we renamed it to `JointPositionCmd`?
content.html:
Thanks for your contribution @Diego Ferigo.

Is there a specific reason for not using the JointVelocityCmd for resetting joint velocities? I understand we don't have a component for setting joint positions so I see the need for JointPositionReset, but would it be a problem if we renamed it to JointPositionCmd?

content.raw:
The operation behind the `JointVelocityCmd` is a bit singular in my opinion. At the moment it can be used only in DART and its introduction in the physics engine is also very recent. However, a real position / velocity reset that changes the state of the simulator is different in nature, and users are typically more familiar with it rather than the current logic behind `JointVelocityCmd`.

As you said, there’s no position reset at the moment. To keep a consistent naming with the components and the logic behind them, I would rather call the real reset components differently. I do not exclude that in the future a new `JointPositionCmd` component will be introduced that, similarly to the logic to create a force that would result to a given velocity, would apply the same logic for the position. I suspect that the majority of the other physics engines that will be wrapped with the physics interfaces will use these `*Reset` components. I have the fear that having the `JointVelocityCmd` that applies a force and the `JointPositionCmd` that, instead, resets the engine state, would just confuse users. What do you think? Of course, using these components responsibly is users duty, and it has to be properly documented.
content.html:
The operation behind the JointVelocityCmd is a bit singular in my opinion. At the moment it can be used only in DART and its introduction in the physics engine is also very recent. However, a real position / velocity reset that changes the state of the simulator is different in nature, and users are typically more familiar with it rather than the current logic behind JointVelocityCmd.

As you said, there’s no position reset at the moment. To keep a consistent naming with the components and the logic behind them, I would rather call the real reset components differently. I do not exclude that in the future a new JointPositionCmd component will be introduced that, similarly to the logic to create a force that would result to a given velocity, would apply the same logic for the position. I suspect that the majority of the other physics engines that will be wrapped with the physics interfaces will use these *Reset components. I have the fear that having the JointVelocityCmd that applies a force and the JointPositionCmd that, instead, resets the engine state, would just confuse users. What do you think? Of course, using these components responsibly is users duty, and it has to be properly documented.

content.raw:
I completely agree with this outlook.

There are valid use cases for directly setting the position and velocity states of entities within the physics engine, typically for initialization or re-initialization. Using a controller to drive the entities towards these states would not be desirable for those use cases \(even if that controller is a very aggressive built-in controller\).

At the same time, it’s important that the ability to directly set the state is not also used as a method to control the dynamics of a simulation, which is what the role of a `Joint[Position|Velocity]Cmd` API would be.

The most important thing is that it’s clear to users what the role of each component is and when it should \(or should not\) be used. I think designating them as `*Reset` and `*Cmd` would do a good job of making that clear to users.
content.html:
I completely agree with this outlook.

There are valid use cases for directly setting the position and velocity states of entities within the physics engine, typically for initialization or re-initialization. Using a controller to drive the entities towards these states would not be desirable for those use cases (even if that controller is a very aggressive built-in controller).

At the same time, it’s important that the ability to directly set the state is not also used as a method to control the dynamics of a simulation, which is what the role of a Joint[Position|Velocity]Cmd API would be.

The most important thing is that it’s clear to users what the role of each component is and when it should (or should not) be used. I think designating them as *Reset and *Cmd would do a good job of making that clear to users.

content.raw: @{dgferigo} You make a good point. I'm good with calling them `*Reset` so that `*Cmd` type components are reserved for values used by built-in controllers.
content.html: @Diego Ferigo You make a good point. I'm good with calling them *Reset so that *Cmd type components are reserved for values used by built-in controllers.

content.raw: Even more, the time of application of `*Cmd` and `*Reset` components is different. In fact, `*Cmd` components would result to the specified amount _after_ the physics step. Instead, `*Reset` components would be applied _before_. In this sense, I see a mismatch with the `JointForceCmd` \(that is applied before\). Again, as I wrote, the current implementation of `JointVelocityCmd` is quite singular and probably it would have deserved a different naming scheme. Though, I understand that right now it might be too late to be changed.
content.html: Even more, the time of application of *Cmd and *Reset components is different. In fact, *Cmd components would result to the specified amount after the physics step. Instead, *Reset components would be applied before. In this sense, I see a mismatch with the JointForceCmd (that is applied before). Again, as I wrote, the current implementation of JointVelocityCmd is quite singular and probably it would have deserved a different naming scheme. Though, I understand that right now it might be too late to be changed.

content.raw: I think it's problematic to remove components inside an `Each` call. Can you collect the entities that have the component in a container and then remove the component in a separate loop? content.raw: I'd expect the `Reset`s, unlike `Cmd`s, to act instantaneously. Why aren't we reaching `pos0` and `vel0` on the tests?
content.html: I'd expect the Resets, unlike Cmds, to act instantaneously. Why aren't we reaching pos0 and vel0 on the tests?

content.raw: I believe the reset only applies for one simulation step so the velocity should be `vel0` in the first test, but in the second test, the joint starts accelerating again, so the velocity would be different.
content.html: I believe the reset only applies for one simulation step so the velocity should be vel0 in the first test, but in the second test, the joint starts accelerating again, so the velocity would be different.

content.raw:
I had a look at it. In the case of the position, the first step of the simulation matches exactly what stored in the `JointPositionReset` component. Instead, for some reason, the velocity does not get reset exactly to 3.0 but 2.9999. I suspect that the origin of this small mismatch is something related to DART.

As @{557058:90bc87b0-2886-4377-a17c-3a6629a697ff} wrote, the second step will differ due to the joint accelerating again.
content.html:
I had a look at it. In the case of the position, the first step of the simulation matches exactly what stored in the JointPositionReset component. Instead, for some reason, the velocity does not get reset exactly to 3.0 but 2.9999. I suspect that the origin of this small mismatch is something related to DART.

As @Addisu Z. Taddese wrote, the second step will differ due to the joint accelerating again.

content.raw: Thank you for the clarification. Having a small mismatch on the 1st iteration sounds ok to me. Ready to approve once the other smaller comments are addressed.
content.html: Thank you for the clarification. Having a small mismatch on the 1st iteration sounds ok to me. Ready to approve once the other smaller comments are addressed.

I think the compiler warning is coming from using `EXPECT_EQ` for doubles. You can use `EXEPCT_DOUBLE_EQ` instead.
content.html: Tests are (with the exception of flaky tests in macOS). There are some style and compiler warnings though. I think the compiler warning is coming from using EXPECT_EQ for doubles. You can use EXEPCT_DOUBLE_EQ instead.

content.raw:
Since this PR is adding a new feature without breaking anything, it can go into ign-gazebo2. We will then forward-port it to ign-gazebo3 after the PR is merged. For now, if you can just merge from ign-gazebo2 to get the latest changes, I will start new builds.

Also, I built your branch locally and it looks like the `EXPECT_EQ` warnings are gone. The following style warnings are still there (you can check with `make codecheck`)
```
[ign-gazebo/test/integration/physics_system.cc:623]: (style) The scope of the variable 'firstRun' can be reduced.
[ign-gazebo/test/integration/physics_system.cc:716]: (style) The scope of the variable 'firstRun' can be reduced.
ign-gazebo/src/systems/physics/Physics.cc:1199:  Missing space around colon in range-based for loop  [whitespace/forcolon] [2]
ign-gazebo/src/systems/physics/Physics.cc:1212:  Missing space around colon in range-based for loop  [whitespace/forcolon] [2]
ign-gazebo/test/integration/physics_system.cc:779:  Missing username in TODO; it should look like "// TODO(my_username): Stuff."  [readability/todo] [2]
Total errors found: 3
```
content.html:
Since this PR is adding a new feature without breaking anything, it can go into ign-gazebo2. We will then forward-port it to ign-gazebo3 after the PR is merged. For now, if you can just merge from ign-gazebo2 to get the latest changes, I will start new builds.

Also, I built your branch locally and it looks like the EXPECT_EQ warnings are gone. The following style warnings are still there (you can check with make codecheck)

[ign-gazebo/test/integration/physics_system.cc:623]: (style) The scope of the variable 'firstRun' can be reduced.
[ign-gazebo/test/integration/physics_system.cc:716]: (style) The scope of the variable 'firstRun' can be reduced.
ign-gazebo/src/systems/physics/Physics.cc:1199:  Missing space around colon in range-based for loop  [whitespace/forcolon] [2]
ign-gazebo/src/systems/physics/Physics.cc:1212:  Missing space around colon in range-based for loop  [whitespace/forcolon] [2]
ign-gazebo/test/integration/physics_system.cc:779:  Missing username in TODO; it should look like "// TODO(my_username): Stuff."  [readability/todo] [2]
Total errors found: 3

content.raw: Thanks! I’m addressing these last warnings. It seems though that the warnings about `firstRun` are wrong, given the current logic I don’t see how their scope could be reduced. If I define them inside the inlined lambda, they won’t be persistent among different simulator steps. Is there any way to suppress the warning for that line only?
content.html: Thanks! I’m addressing these last warnings. It seems though that the warnings about firstRun are wrong, given the current logic I don’t see how their scope could be reduced. If I define them inside the inlined lambda, they won’t be persistent among different simulator steps. Is there any way to suppress the warning for that line only?

hmm, those do seem like false positives, probably related to this ticket: https://trac.cppcheck.net/ticket/8541. You can suppress them using 

// cppcheck-suppress variableScope
bool firstRun = true;
